title: 113_s915
content: The Act titled "Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2013" amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to include additional requirements for program participation agreements. This includes providing institutional and financial assistance information to students. Section 485 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to align institutional reporting requirements with IPEDS data metrics. The Secretary will issue guidance on duplicative data metrics within 6 months of the Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2013. Institutions must link to an institutional reporting website within 5 years of the Act. Institutions must provide a prominently displayed link on their website to a specific website as determined by the Secretary under the Higher Education Act of 1965. SEC. 4. INSTITUTIONAL REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Amendment to Database of Student Information Prohibited. Reporting Requirements under Section 493E. Institutions of higher education must submit data to the Secretary for the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System. The Secretary will provide guidance on data submission within a year of the Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2013. Data categories for submission will be reviewed every 5 years. Additional student classifications may be established. The Secretary will establish common definitions and requirements for institutions to submit data on student unit records, including participation in remedial education, degree-seeking status, and certificate pursuit. The Secretary will establish new outcome metrics for data submitted under subsection (a) to calculate student components of IPEDS, including measures related to student financial aid at institutional and program levels. The Secretary will establish new outcome metrics for data submitted under subsection (a) to calculate student components of IPEDS, including measures related to student financial aid such as federal loans, state grants, state loans, institutional grants, and institutional loans. This includes tracking the average amount of total federal loan debt assumed by students upon graduation and after 2 years for students who do not complete a program of study. Additionally, student transfer rates by sector of transfer will be monitored. The Secretary will establish new outcome metrics for data submitted under subsection (a) to calculate student components of IPEDS, including measures related to student financial aid and student transfer rates by sector of transfer. This includes tracking federal loan debt, state grants, institutional grants, and student outcomes such as continuation to higher education and degree attainment. The Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2013 requires student level components of IPEDS to be reported based on different student types: those who received a Federal Pell Grant, those who received a Federal Stafford Loan but not a Pell Grant, those who received neither, and veterans who received assistance under the Post-9/11 Veterans Educational Assistance Program. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must coordinate with the Secretary to provide data for reporting enrollment status of different student types under chapter 33 of title 38, United States Code. This includes details on first-time, full-time students, first-time, part-time students, non-first-time, full-time students, and non-first-time, part-time students, as well as enrollment intensity. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must coordinate with the Secretary to provide data for reporting enrollment status of different student types under chapter 33 of title 38, United States Code, including details on enrollment intensity. The Secretary, in cooperation with the Commissioner of Social Security, shall establish a system to create earnings metrics based on educational program and credential received. The Secretary, in cooperation with the Commissioner of Social Security, shall establish standard time periods for reporting earnings outcomes based on educational program completion, credential received, educational institution, and State of employment. The information will be publicly available in a user-friendly manner without personally identifiable information. The Secretary will publish student components of IPEDS for 5 years after the enactment of the Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2013. The Secretary will consult with State offices for data collections, excluding the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act. The Secretary will consult with State offices and institutions of higher education to develop calculation and reporting standards for student-level data collections. Personally identifiable information of students shall not be shared, except as necessary for reporting and data dissemination purposes under the Act. The Secretary will create a process for institutions to request aggregate student outcome data for institutional improvement and program evaluation. Regulations will ensure fair access to the data. Procedures will be developed for institutional review of merged data used for Federal accountability. Privacy and security measures will be in place for the data system. The data system developed under this section focuses on identity protection, data audit, and governance systems to ensure compliance with Federal standards. It prohibits unauthorized use of individual data collected under this section. The data system developed under this section ensures individual privacy by prohibiting federal action based on collected data and issuing guidelines for institutions to update privacy notices. The system does not disclose personally identifiable information and complies with privacy requirements. The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act and other privacy laws require a policy on data use to prevent unauthorized disclosure. Penalties include fines and imprisonment for willful disclosure of personal identifiers. Appropriations are authorized for implementation. Appropriations are authorized for each fiscal year from 2014 to 2022 to carry out the necessary sums for this section.
